vulnerabilities.summary: A DCE/RPC service is running on the remote host.
vulnerabilities.description:
By sending a Lookup request to the portmapper (TCP 135 or epmapper PIPE) it was possible to enumerate the Distributed Computing Environment (DCE) services running on the remote port.
Using this information it is possible to connect and bind to each service by sending an RPC request to the remote port/pipe.

vulnerabilities.summary: The remote host's hostname is not consistent with DNS information.
vulnerabilities.description:
The name of this machine either does not resolve or resolves to a different IP address. 

This may come from a badly configured reverse DNS or from a host file in use on the Nessus scanning host. 

As a result, URLs in plugin output may not be directly usable in a web browser and some web tests may be incomplete.
vulnerabilities.solution: Fix the reverse DNS or host file.

vulnerabilities.summary: It was possible to resolve the name of the remote host.
vulnerabilities.description: Nessus was able to resolve the FQDN of the remote host.

vulnerabilities.summary: It was possible to obtain traceroute information.
vulnerabilities.description: Makes a traceroute to the remote host.

vulnerabilities.summary: The Nessus scan of this host may be incomplete due to insufficient privileges provided.
vulnerabilities.description:
The Nessus scanner testing the remote host has been given SMB credentials to log into the remote host, however these credentials do not have administrative privileges. 

Typically, when Nessus performs a patch audit, it logs into the remote host and reads the version of the DLLs on the remote host to determine if a given patch has been applied or not.  This is the method Microsoft recommends to determine if a patch has been applied. 

If your Nessus scanner does not have administrative privileges when doing a scan, then Nessus has to fall back to perform a patch audit through the registry which may lead to false positives (especially when using third-party patch auditing tools) or to false negatives (not all patches can be detected through the registry).
vulnerabilities.solution: Reconfigure your scanner to use credentials with administrative privileges.

vulnerabilities.summary: Nessus is not able to access the remote Windows Registry.
vulnerabilities.description:
It was not possible to connect to PIPE\winreg on the remote host.

If you intend to use Nessus to perform registry-based checks, the registry checks will not work because the 'Remote Registry Access' service (winreg) has been disabled on the remote host or can not be connected to with the supplied credentials.

vulnerabilities.summary: It is possible to determine which TCP ports are open.
vulnerabilities.description:
This plugin is a SYN 'half-open' port scanner.
It shall be reasonably quick even against a firewalled target.

Note that SYN scanners are less intrusive than TCP (full connect) scanners against broken services, but they might kill lame misconfigured firewalls. They might also leave unclosed connections on the remote target, if the network is loaded.
vulnerabilities.solution: Protect your target with an IP filter.

vulnerabilities.summary: It is possible to log into the remote host.
vulnerabilities.description:
The remote host is running Microsoft Windows operating system or Samba, a CIFS/SMB server for Unix.  It was possible to log into it using one of the following accounts :

- NULL session
- Guest account
- Given Credentials

vulnerabilities.summary: It is possible to obtain information about the remote operating system.
vulnerabilities.description: It is possible to get the remote operating system name and version (Windows and/or Samba) by sending an authentication request to port 139 or 445.

vulnerabilities.summary: It is possible to obtain the network name of the remote host.
vulnerabilities.description:
The remote host listens on UDP port 137 or TCP port 445 and replies to NetBIOS nbtscan or SMB requests. 

Note that this plugin gathers information to be used in other plugins but does not itself generate a report.

vulnerabilities.summary: This plugin determines which HTTP methods are allowed on various CGI directories.
vulnerabilities.description:
By calling the OPTIONS method, it is possible to determine which HTTP methods are allowed on each directory. 

As this list may be incomplete, the plugin also tests - if 'Thorough tests' are enabled or 'Enable web applications tests' is set to 'yes' in the scan policy - various known HTTP methods on each directory and considers them as unsupported if it receives a response code of 400, 403, 405, or 501. 

Note that the plugin output is only informational and does not necessarily indicate the presence of any security vulnerabilities.
